Legal_Issue: Whether intermediates used in the synthesis of Cefaclor are considered 'medicines' under the Regulations
Governing_Law: Regulations defining 'medicine' as substances intended or capable of being used for diagnosis, treatment, mitigation, or prevention of a disease
Evidence_Assessment: Intermediates have no therapeutic properties and cannot be used for diagnosis, treatment, etc.
Legal_Rule: Substances must be intended or capable of being used for diagnosis, treatment, mitigation, or prevention of a disease to be considered 'medicines'
Grounds_for_Claim: Lilly sought to prohibit Apotex from obtaining Notices of Compliance based on patents for intermediates
Outcome_on_Merits: Intermediates are not medicines; patents improperly listed
Key_Evidence_Considered: Therapeutic properties (or lack thereof) of intermediates
Applicant_Challenge: Lilly's attempt to block Apotex's Notices of Compliance
Court_Result: Apotex can proceed with Notices of Compliance without infringing improperly listed patents
Defendant_Response: Intermediates are not medicines and thus patent listing is improper
Remedy_Requested: Prevention of Apotex obtaining Notices of Compliance
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Patents for non-medicinal intermediates improperly listed
Applicable_Process: Notice of Compliance proceedings under patent linkage regulations
